Research

LiDAR-Informed, Terrain-Adaptive Invariant Kalman Filtering for Legged Robots

Authors: Saaketh Reddy, Ziwon Yoon
Status: In Progress

This paper presents a terrain-aware invariant extended Kalman filter (InEKF) that adapts its covariance online using LiDAR-derived terrain information. A neural network maps geometric and structural terrain cues to context-dependent uncertainty adjustments, allowing the estimator to modulate trust in kinematic odometry under varying contact and slip conditions for legged robots.

Wendy N. Newcomb, Saaketh Reddy, Aprameya Satish, Alessio Medda; Time-frequency spectral optimization of underwater sonar acoustic returns for the purpose of characterization using spectral descriptors J. Acoust. Soc. Am. 1 October 2024; 156 (4_Supplement): A25–A26

Abstract:
This work studies time-varying underwater sonar returns to extract object and seafloor characteristics relevant to mine countermeasures. It compares several time-frequency representations (STFT, smoothed pseudo Wigner–Ville, empirical wavelet, and chirplet transforms) using spectral concentration and resolution metrics. The impact of optimized transforms is evaluated through time-frequency spectral descriptors.

Keywords: Keywords: underwater sonar, time-frequency analysis, spectral concentration, mine countermeasures

Research Experience

Lidar Lab ~ Dr.Ye Zhao

August 2022 – May 2025

  • Implemented an Invariant Extended Kalman Filter (InEKF) for state estimation on the Agility Robotics’ Digit, Unitree’s G1 and Go2 robots in real time.
  • Conducted an investigative study of MuJoCo simulation parameters to analyze their effects on Digit’s walking behaviors
  • Optimized path planning and obstacle avoidance by implementing object clustering, reducing processing time by 80%
  • Engineered an innovative gear-pulley actuation mechanism for a parallel gripper to precisely track and transmit servo torque
  • Led the creation of silicone molds manufacturing and making

Environmental Fluid Mechanics Lab ~ Dr. Mohammad Mohaghar

January 2025 – August 2025

  • Successfully led an undergraduate team to design and prototype a magnetically actuated, jellyfish-inspired soft robot
  • Polarizer sim
  • Led undergrad team
